verses.text: In the second year of Nebuchadnezzar's reign, Nebuchadnezzar dreamed dreams, and his spirit was troubled so that his sleep left him.
verses.comment: As with Pharaoh (Genesis 41:1), God uses dreams to reveal his sovereign will to rulers and unsettle their spirits for a purpose.

verses.text: Then the king commanded to summon the magicians, the sorcerers, the enchanters, and the Chaldeans to tell the king his dreams. So they came in and stood before the king.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar seeks wisdom from pagans, highlighting the contrast between divine wisdom and human wisdom found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: And the king said to them, 'I have dreamed a dream, and my spirit is anxious to understand the dream.'
verses.comment: Dreams often signify God's message or warning, creating an occasion for God to demonstrate His supremacy through His servants.

verses.text: Then the Chaldeans spoke to the king in Aramaic, 'O king, live forever! Tell your servants the dream, and we will show the interpretation.'
verses.comment: From this verse, the text shifts into Aramaic (until 7:28), emphasizing the message for all nations. The Chaldeans' flattery contrasts with the honesty of God's true prophets.

verses.text: The king answered the Chaldeans, 'The thing is firm with me: if you do not make known to me the dream and its interpretation, you shall be cut in pieces, and your houses shall be made a ruin heap.'
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s harsh decree underlines the seriousness of the matter, and the inability of human wisdom apart from divine revelation.

verses.text: But if you show the dream and its interpretation, you shall receive gifts and rewards and great honor from me. Therefore show me the dream and its interpretation.
verses.comment: The king tests the authenticity of his wise men. Only true revelation deserves reward, a principle echoed through God’s prophets.

verses.text: They answered again and said, 'Let the king tell his servants the dream, and we will show the interpretation.'
verses.comment: Human wisdom wants clues; only the divine can reveal hidden secrets.

verses.text: The king replied, 'I know for certain that you are trying to gain time, because you see that the thing is firmly decreed by me.'
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar suspects delay and demands true authority—a theme reinforced throughout Daniel.

verses.text: 'If you will not make the dream known to me, there is only one decree for you. For you have agreed to speak lying and corrupt words before me till the times change. Therefore tell me the dream, and I shall know that you can show me its interpretation.'
verses.comment: True prophetic authority is tested by the ability to reveal the unknown.

verses.text: The Chaldeans answered the king and said, 'There is no man on earth who can reveal the king's matter, for no king, lord, or ruler has asked such a thing of any magician, enchanter, or Chaldean.'
verses.comment: Their admission prepares the way for God alone—through His chosen servant—to make known His mysteries.

verses.text: 'The thing that the king asks is difficult, and there is no one who can show it to the king except the gods, whose dwelling is not with flesh.'
verses.comment: Gentiles recognize their spiritual limits. The phrase foreshadows the later mystery of God dwelling among men (see John 1:14).

verses.text: Because of this the king was angry and very furious, and commanded that all the wise men of Babylon be destroyed.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s emotional reaction sets events in motion to display God's sovereignty.

verses.text: So the decree went out, and the wise men were about to be killed; and they sought Daniel and his companions, to kill them.
verses.comment: Daniel and his friends are included, showing the testing of the faithful among the nations.

verses.text: Then Daniel spoke with wisdom and tact to Arioch, the captain of the king's guard, who had gone out to kill the wise men of Babylon.
verses.comment: Daniel’s prudence contrasts with the rashness of the magicians. God’s servants counsel with wisdom.

verses.text: He answered and said to Arioch, the king's captain, 'Why is the decree from the king so harsh?' Then Arioch made the thing known to Daniel.
verses.comment: Daniel dares to question the injustice, trusting God’s provision.

verses.text: So Daniel went in and asked the king to give him time, that he might show the king the interpretation.
verses.comment: Daniel’s confidence is in the living God, not in occult practices.

verses.text: Then Daniel went to his house and made the matter known to Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, his companions,
verses.comment: The unity and prayerfulness of the faithful echo God’s chosen people gathering together throughout salvation history.

verses.text: and told them to seek mercy from the God of heaven concerning this mystery, so that Daniel and his companions might not be destroyed with the rest of the wise men of Babylon.
verses.comment: Petitioning God for mercy is central to biblical faith. God is shown as the revealer of mysteries.

verses.text: Then the mystery was revealed to Daniel in a vision of the night. Then Daniel blessed the God of heaven.
verses.comment: God answers prayer through revelation, emphasizing the supernatural role in true guidance and authority.

verses.text: Daniel answered, saying: 'Blessed be the name of God forever and ever, for wisdom and might belong to him.'
verses.comment: A hymn of praise, reminding believers that only God is the source of wisdom and power.

verses.text: He changes times and seasons; he removes kings and establishes kings; he gives wisdom to the wise and knowledge to those who understand.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over history and rulers foreshadows the coming of a divine kingdom.

verses.text: He reveals deep and hidden things; he knows what is in the darkness, and the light dwells with him.
verses.comment: God’s light, later revealed in Christ, overcomes the darkness (John 1:9). His authority embraces both physical and spiritual realms.

verses.text: 'To you, O God of my fathers, I give thanks and praise, for you have given me wisdom and might, and have made known to me what we asked of you, for you have made known to us the king’s matter.'
verses.comment: Daniel acknowledges continuity with the faith of his forefathers, echoing the living tradition passed down through the generations.

verses.text: Therefore Daniel went in to Arioch, whom the king had appointed to destroy the wise men of Babylon, and said to him, 'Do not destroy the wise men of Babylon; bring me in before the king, and I will show the king the interpretation.'
verses.comment: Daniel’s intervention saves the unjust as well as the faithful, revealing God’s mercy toward all.

verses.text: Then Arioch quickly brought Daniel before the king and said, 'I have found among the exiles from Judah a man who will make known to the king the interpretation.'
verses.comment: Daniel, a member of the faithful remnant, stands before the greatest human power, anticipating the stronger testimony of God’s Kingdom.

verses.text: The king declared to Daniel, whose name was Belteshazzar, 'Are you able to make known to me the dream that I have seen and its interpretation?'
verses.comment: Daniel’s Hebrew name is recalled, showing faithfulness amid assimilation.

verses.text: Daniel answered the king and said, 'No wise men, enchanters, magicians, or astrologers can show to the king the mystery that the king has asked,'
verses.comment: Daniel confesses human inability before directly pointing to God as the true source of revelation.

verses.text: 'but there is a God in heaven who reveals mysteries. He has made known to King Nebuchadnezzar what will be in the latter days. Your dream and the visions of your head as you lay in bed are these:'
verses.comment: A clear teaching that only God reveals prophecies and future mysteries, anticipating New Testament teaching on revealed mysteries.

verses.text: 'To you, O king, as you lay in bed, thoughts came into your mind about what would happen after this, and he who reveals mysteries made known to you what is to be.'
verses.comment: God proactively reveals future events, underlying His providential control over history.

verses.text: 'But as for me, this mystery has not been revealed to me because of any wisdom that I have more than all the living, but in order that the interpretation may be made known to the king, and that you may understand the thoughts of your mind.'
verses.comment: Daniel humbly acknowledges his role as a vessel of divine revelation, not the source.

verses.text: 'You, O king, were looking, and behold, there was a great statue. This image, mighty and exceedingly bright, stood before you; and its appearance was terrifying.'
verses.comment: The image’s overwhelming impression parallels later apocalyptic visions of worldly kingdoms.

verses.text: 'The head of this image was of fine gold, its chest and arms of silver, its belly and thighs of bronze,'
verses.comment: The descending value of metals symbolizes the diminishing glory and unity of subsequent kingdoms.

verses.text: 'its legs of iron, its feet partly of iron and partly of clay.'
verses.comment: The mixed materials symbolize the divided strength and instability of later kingdoms.

verses.text: 'As you watched, a stone was cut out, but not by human hands, and it struck the image on its feet of iron and clay, and broke them in pieces.'
verses.comment: The 'stone cut without hands' is a prophecy of a divine, eternal kingdom, interpreted by Christ as referring to Himself (see Luke 20:17–18).

verses.text: 'Then the iron, the clay, the bronze, the silver, and the gold were all broken in pieces and became like chaff of the summer threshing floors; and the wind carried them away so that not a trace of them could be found. But the stone that struck the image became a great mountain and filled the whole earth.'
verses.comment: God's kingdom, established supernaturally, surpasses and replaces all worldly powers and endures forever.

verses.text: 'This was the dream; now we will tell the king its interpretation.'
verses.comment: Daniel’s certainty marks his message as divinely guaranteed.

verses.text: 'You, O king, are the king of kings, to whom the God of heaven has given the kingdom, the power, the might, and the glory,'
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s power is from God—even pagan rulers carry out God’s designs.

verses.text: 'and into whose hand he has given, wherever they dwell, the children of men, the beasts of the field, and the birds of the heavens, making you rule over them all—you are the head of gold.'
verses.comment: This dominion echoes Adam’s stewardship (Gen. 1:28), but even the greatest rulers yield to God’s plan.

verses.text: 'After you shall arise another kingdom inferior to you, and yet a third kingdom of bronze, which shall rule over all the earth.'
verses.comment: The historic succession of empires is foretold; the pattern all leads to the final, divine kingdom.

verses.text: 'And there shall be a fourth kingdom, strong as iron, because iron breaks to pieces and shatters all things; and as iron crushes, so it shall break and crush all these.'
verses.comment: Traditionally interpreted as the Roman Empire; its strength foreshadows the time of the Messiah.

verses.text: 'And as you saw the feet and toes, partly of potter’s clay and partly of iron, it shall be a divided kingdom, but some of the firmness of iron shall be in it, just as you saw iron mixed with clay.'
verses.comment: The mixture of materials points to the inherent weakness and division of human powers apart from divine unity.

verses.text: 'As the toes of the feet were partly iron and partly clay, so the kingdom shall be partly strong and partly brittle.'
verses.comment: The divided nature of the final kingdom leaves space for a single, undivided and eternal kingdom to be established.

verses.text: 'As you saw the iron mixed with soft clay, so they will mix with one another in marriage, but they will not hold together, just as iron does not mix with clay.'
verses.comment: Earthly alliances and unions are inherently unstable compared to the unity of God’s people.

verses.text: 'And in the days of those kings the God of heaven will set up a kingdom that shall never be destroyed, nor shall the kingdom be left to another people. It shall break in pieces all these kingdoms and bring them to an end, and it shall stand forever,'
verses.comment: This everlasting kingdom is fulfilled in Christ. Its perpetuity points toward a visible, apostolic community enduring through history (see Matt. 16:18–19).

verses.text: 'just as you saw that a stone was cut from a mountain by no human hand, and that it broke in pieces the iron, the bronze, the clay, the silver, and the gold. The great God has made known to the king what shall be after this. The dream is certain, and its interpretation sure.'
verses.comment: Supernatural origins are a hallmark of God’s true kingdom and teaching. The finality and assurance echo later prophetic and apostolic confidence.

verses.text: Then King Nebuchadnezzar fell on his face and paid homage to Daniel, and ordered that an offering and incense be offered up to him.
verses.comment: Nebuchadnezzar’s worship reveals awe at genuine divine power, but true servants direct this to God (compare Acts 10:25–26).

verses.text: The king answered Daniel and said, 'Truly, your God is the God of gods and Lord of kings, and a revealer of mysteries, for you have been able to reveal this mystery.'
verses.comment: Pagan kings confess God's supremacy when His works are manifested. This prefigures the later confession of the nations after Christ’s victory.

verses.text: Then the king gave Daniel high honors and many great gifts, and made him ruler over the whole province of Babylon and chief administrator over all the wise men of Babylon.
verses.comment: God’s servant is exalted to leadership and service, foreshadowing the reward of the faithful in God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Daniel made a request to the king, and he appointed Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego over the affairs of the province of Babylon. But Daniel remained at the king’s court.
verses.comment: Faithful prayer and intercession bless the community—a pattern of godly leadership and unity. Daniel’s ongoing presence ensures continual guidance.
